encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: 19[Emblem 19]

The Elephant
(Emblem 19)
AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

Elephants provide the model for a surprising number of virtues in this poem. If upper-class Royalists in England had emulated their piety, industriousness, bravery, and fidelity, Pulter suggests, they might have turned the political tide and prevented the regicide of King Charles I, along with the side benefit of keeping their wives in line. Drawing on moralizing natural histories, Pulter excoriates the elites of her own class for their interlaced personal and political failures, flaws which extend into the realm of sexuality. Gentlemen, she advises directly at the poem’s conclusion, need to stop wasting their time by gallivanting about, drinking and gambling. If they don’t attend to their mates (which the male elephants do so scrupulously that they murder mates suspected of infidelity), they are likely to wind up with wives who fritter away their time attending plays, frequenting taverns, and committing adultery. The elephant’s graceful bowing to the rising sun, with which the emblem begins, gives way to a stern lecture on how the social hierarchy may crumble under the weight of its own immorality.

app.rdg: 19The Eliphant when Raidiant Sol Doth Riſe
The elephant, when radiant Solpersonification of the Sun and an ancient Roman god doth rise,
Devoutly bows with Elevated Eyes
Devoutly bows; with elevated eyes
Hee offers up his Morning Sacrifice
He offers up his morning sacrifice.
Some may perhaps this vain Religion Sleight

Some may perhaps this vain religionPulter’s description of the elephants’ worship, which may seem “vain” (idle, unprofitable, useless) to some, is drawn from Edward Topsell: “They have also a kind of Religion, for they worship, reverence, and observe the course of the Sun, Moon, and Stars … they reverence the Sun rising, holding up their trunk or hand to heaven, in congratulation of her rising” (Edward Topsell, History of Four-Footed Beasts [1607], p. 192; cited by Stefan Christian, “The Poems of Lady Hester Pulter (1605?–1678): An Annotated Edition.” PhD diss. [University of Massachusetts Amherst, 2012], p. 310). slight,
But of all Creatures I would Worſhip Light
But of all creaturescreated things; the created universe, I would worship light.
Their vallour too the Orient Kingdooms trie
Theirthe elephants’ valor too the Orient kingdoms trythe countries in the East “try” (test or prove),
&ff;or in the &ff;eild they’l bravly &ff;ighting die
For in the field they’ll bravely fighting die;
And when the Indians theſe beaſts doe Hire

And when the Indians these beasts do hirePulter’s description of the elephants as launching ships, fighting in battle, and mating is based on Pliny, The History of the World, trans. Philemon Holland (London, 1634), 8th chapter, pp. 192-99.
To Lanch their Ships, when one begins to tire
To launch their ships, when one begins to tire,
Thel’e bring another to lift in his place
They’ll bring another to lift in his place;
But Rather then hee’l ^live to know diſgrace
But rather than he’ll live to know disgrace,
Hee’l draw and Shov’e not onely till hee tires
He’ll draw and shove not only till he tires,
But Straining Bursts and Soe his Soul expires
But straining, bursts; and so his soul expires,
As Rather chooſing to Abrupt his Story
As rather choosing to abruptbreak off his storylife
Then live and let another take his Glory
Than live and let another take his glory.
&ff;or Chastitie this Gallant Creature’s Crown’d
For chastity this gallantattractive in manners; excellent, admirable creature’s crowned,
&ff;or when hee hath a Lovly &ff;emale &ff;ound
For when he hath a lovely female found
And mutuall &ff;lames doe in their boſomes Glow
And mutual flames do in their bosoms glow,
They modestly into the Shades doe goe
They modestly into the shadesshadows do go;
There free from Company that might Annoy
There, free from company that might annoy,
They Innocently each other doe Injoy
They innocently each other do enjoy.
Yet hee’s Soe tender of his Reputation
Yet he’s so tender ofconcerned with his reputation
Hee kills his &ff;emale if hee doubts Scortation
He kills his female if he doubts scortationfears adultery.
By this the Gallants of our Age may See
By this the gallantsmen of fashion and pleasure; fine gentlemen (sometimes ironic); those who pay attention to ladies; lovers or (derogatively) paramours of our age may see,
In beeing Athiest’s worſ then Beaſts theydarker “h” possibly over another letter bee
In being atheiststhose who deny or disbelieve the existence of God but used as an anti-Royalist label for religious or political opponents in England’s civil war, worse than beasts they be.
Like them in Noble Actions Strive to exceed
Like them in noble actionsBe like them in noble actions; this is directed to the reader, strive to exceed
Each other, this Want did make Us Bleed
Each other: this wantlack or flaw did make us bleed
In our brave King, for had you valiant been

In our brave kingCharles I, executed by beheading in 1649; “this want did make us bleed / In our brave king” suggests that a flaw in England or its nobility led to the nation metaphorically losing blood when the king bled (at his execution).. For had you valiant been,
Soe Sad A changedarker “e” possibly in different hand from main scribe as this wee ne’re had Seen
So sad a change as this we ne’er had seen.
&ff;or had not Lords in Noble breeding faild
For had not lords in noble breeding failedPulter suggests that aristocrats (“lords”), also known as nobles, failed to live up to their upbringing as such (thus invoking “noble” in its moral sense).,
Tin^ckers and Coblers never had prevaild
Tinkers and cobblerspot-menders and shoemakers; here, representatives of commoners never had prevailed.
But wee our Wants and loſſes may deplore
ButNothing but we our wants and losses may deplorelament,
But Sin alone that Sets us on the Score
But sin alone, that sets us on the scorecauses us to be in debt.
Then yet bee chast and thoſe you chooſe in youth
Then yet be chaste, and those you choose in youth,
Loue Conſtantly for truth deſerveth Truth
Love constantly, for truthhere, in the sense of fidelity (i.e., marital fidelity to “those you choose in youth”) deserveth truth.
Neglect them not, to drink, Rant, throw ye Die

Neglect them not, to drink, rant, throw the diedrink alcohol, “rant” (be jovial, boisterous, or uproariously merry; lead a riotous or dissolute life; sing loudly, dance or play music), or gamble (throw dice),
&ff;or to temptation then they open lie
For to temptation then theythe wives open lie.
In comon meetings they fool out their days

In common meetingspublic gatherings open to all classes of people; “common” could refer to the community of a people or place, or the subset distinguished as from those of higher rank; it was sometimes used as a slur to imply lower-class status. they fool out their days
At Bauls, and Taverns, Seeing Wanton Plays
At balls and taverns, seeing wantonrebellious, unruly, lawless; lustful, inciting lasciviousness; profligate, wasteful; frivolous, pleasure-seeking plays.
To Cenſure you In earnest I am Loth
To censure you in earnest I am loathaverse, reluctant,
But Sure you want or,comma erased imperfectly Vallour, Witt, or both
But sure you want or valor, wityou lack either bravery or “wit” (reason, intellect), or both.
Your Ladyes are Soe Laviſh of their &ff;ames

Your ladies are so lavish of their fameseither the noblewomen are so extravagant or undisciplined in spending money that their reputations are damaged; or they are so extravagant in circulating that they get bad reputations,
They have quite out gone our Wanton Citty Dames
They have quite outgone our wanton city damesexceeded unruly or lustful London-based, non-elite women.
&ff;or Honnours Sake looke too’t, for Shame at least
For honor’s sake look to’tto it; here referring to moral behavior in general, or attending to their wives in particular; for shame at least!
You See a Wittall is below a Beast.
You see a wittola contented man who knows that his wife is unfaithful; also, a half-witted person is below a beast.
